duck: Reduction (philosophy) - In philosophy, reduction is the process by which one object, property, concept, theory, etc., is shown to be explicable in terms of another, lower level, entity.
A semisimple module is one in which each submodule is a direct summand.
Relating to, being an instance of, or exhibiting reductionism.
A semisimple Lie algebra is a Lie algebra that is a direct sum of simple Lie algebras.

A semisimple operator (or matrix) is one for which every invariant subspace has an invariant complement. This is equivalent to the minimal polynomial being square-free. Over an algebraically closed field it is equivalent to diagonalizable.
In mathematics, the term semisimple is used in a number of related ways, within different subjects.
A semisimple algebra (or ring) is one that is semisimple as a module over itself.
A semisimple algebraic group is a linear algebraic group whose radical of the identity component is trivial.

wiki.text:
In mathematics, the term 'semisimple' (sometimes 'completely reducible') is used
in a number of related ways, within different subjects. The common theme is the
idea of a decomposition into 'simple' ('irreducible') parts, that fit together
in the cleanest way (by direct sum). Briefly, "semisimple = direct sum of
simple", or equivalently "completely reducible = direct sum of irreducible".

*A semisimple module is one in which each submodule is a direct summand. *A
semisimple algebra (or ring) is one that is semisimple as a module over itself.
*A semisimple operator (or matrix) is one for which every invariant subspace has
an invariant complement. This is equivalent to the minimal polynomial being square-
free. Over an algebraically closed field it is equivalent to diagonalizable. *A
semisimple Lie algebra is a Lie algebra that is a direct sum of simple Lie
algebras. *A semisimple algebraic group is a linear algebraic group whose
radical of the identity component is trivial.
wiki.title: semisimple
